results.title: Devrim
results.creator_credit: Migrant Women's Film Group, Amelia Flores, Zynet Kesting and Mandy King
results.brief_description: Looks at the situation of a young Turkish woman who finds herself in an impossible marriage. Explores her dilemmas, her conditioning both as a migrant and as a woman, and shows how she eventually deals with these. The program is told from a migrant’s perspective, having been written, produced and directed by a group of six migrant women from different countries and backgrounds. Raises issues about migrant women’s lives in Australia, particularly domestic violence.

results.title: Play Loud
results.brief_description:
The distinctive Australian ‘pub rock’ sound was born in the hotels and bars of our major cities in the 1970s.
In the Melbourne scene, the ‘beer barns’ of the suburbs were complemented by smaller, more intimate venues in the city and inner suburbs of Carlton, Richmond, Fitzroy and St Kilda.
This film - made in his student days by award-winning producer Daniel Scharf - presents a 1979 performance by the Melbourne band ‘Cuban Heels’ at one such venue, ‘Hearts’ in Carlton.
The atmosphere of alcohol, cigarette-smoke and youthful exuberance is captured by the camera as it wanders through the audience and lingers on the dancers.
On stage, the band (led by Steve Connolly, who was later the guitarist with Paul Kelly’s ‘Coloured Girls’ and ‘Messengers’ bands) sings a song that could only be a product of the 1970s - about ‘the system’ and the coming revolution.

results.title: From Jean-Paul Sartre to Teresa Teng: Cantonese Contemporary Art in the 1980s
results.creator_credit: Clair Hsu, , Siren Films and Arts Asia Archive
results.brief_description:
Interviews with leading Cantonese artists and their memories of a developing art scene in the 1980s.

“The 1980s was a seminal period in the history of contemporary art in China. However, the contribution and experimentalism of the art scene in South China, in particular, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, have generally been overlooked. Due to the proximity of Hong Kong, western ideas from translated books and articles, as well as popular culture in the form of TV shows and Canto pop, flooded over the border to Guangdong at the end of the Cultural Revolution. This influx of new ideas and popular culture sparked great excitement, debate and experimentation in the arts.

Based on primary research, rare film footage and personal interviews with key artists, this documentary bears witness not only to the reading fever that gripped the Chinese art world in the 1980s, but also highlights the experimentalism and verve of artists and critics in South China whose contributions to the development of contemporary art have been long lasting and fundamental.” Source: Arts Asia Archive [www.aaa.org.hk]

Interviewees include: Chen Shaoxiong, Chen Tong, Deng Jianjin, Feng Yuan, Hou Hanru, Huang Xiaopeng, Li Zhengtian, Lin Yilin, Shao Hong, Wang Du, Wang Huangsheng, Xu Tan, Yang Jiechang and Yang Xiaoyan.

results.title: The Lost Thing
results.creator_credit: Shaun Tan, Sophie Byrne, Andrew Ruhemann and Passion Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, this Oscar Award winning animated short film of Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’, tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeonholes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Shaun Tan, Sophie Byrne, Andrew Ruhemann and Passion Pictures

results.title: Journey of a Nation
results.creator_credit: Catherine Duncan, John Heyer, Australian National Film Board and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: This film deals with the need for unification of rail gauges in Australia by showing just what the breaks in gauge at the States’ borders mean to the people who have to ship their goods interstate; particularly primary producers. It also makes a very lively plea for unification, treating its subject humanly, stressing the vital importance of rail transportation in a continent of such vast distances as Australia.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine Duncan, John Heyer, Australian National Film Board and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: In the Mind's Eye
results.creator_credit: Emma Buckland, David Blake and Jess Chapkoun
results.brief_description:
The final outcome from a work experience project with Swinburne Unversity of Technology (TAFE) Multimedia Course, Computing and IT Department. “How do you communicate? Do you really listen? Do you respond to what’s been said or do you just talk about your own memory and experience? Dive into “The minds
eye”, a small film that explores what it will take for us to pay attention and react. Directed Written and Produced by Jess Chapkoun, Emma Buckland and David Blake.
Music by Susan Ellis & Stuart Porter and Ivan Rosa & Matthew Farrington

results.title: Going Solo
results.brief_description:
Through life experiences such as divorce, bereavement or never meeting the right soulmate we may find ourselves fifty plus and living on our own. For some in this situation a new partner is not what they crave, just the supportive friendship of those who understand.

Based on a series of interviews conducted with members of a Catholic Women’s solo group, this 36 min amateur documentary is a first time effort for the filmmaker and although the production values are at times questionable - the heart and soul of the women interviewed shine through making this a warm, often funny and inspirational account of life for a growing number of people in our community.

results.title: Thrownness
results.brief_description:
Two people are thrown into a strange, mysterious place where nothing is as it appears to be and where the relation between cause and effect is never stable. As they explore their surroundings they discover that space, time and themselves are elements of a carefully constructed illusion. Thrownness has been inspired by Matthew Arnold’s poem, ‘Dover Beach’ and philosopher Martin Heidegger. Arnold’s poem of 1867 has surprising contemporary relevance in a time where ‘ignorant armies clash by night’. The romantic photography reminiscent of 1950 Technicolor films, fantastical sets inspired by Fellini’s films and the use of old style in-camera effects create an intriguing, magical aesthetic.

As viewers Thrownness asks us to consider our role in creating narrative coherence through our understanding of cinematic traditions and visual language. The story has an integral, essential and evolving relationship with the elements that create it. The effect of this is the generation of an unexpected alternative narrative which reveals the complex artifice that is the film language.

results.title: Jirrupin Bunggul 'Happy Dance'
results.brief_description: Winner of the ‘Make a stamp come alive’ category of Screen It! This cool little work combines a thumping dance track with animation of the artwork depicted on an Australian stamp entitled ‘Aboriginal Culture: Music and Dance’. An animated short entered to ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.
